step1_initial_points.title: Inefficient Manual Legal Workflows
step1_initial_points.description: Lawyers spend significant time on low-value, repetitive tasks like summarizing lengthy documents, creating case chronologies, and drafting initial communications. This reduces efficiency, slows service delivery, and diverts focus from high-value strategic legal analysis.

step1_initial_points.title: Difficulty Leveraging Internal Knowledge
step1_initial_points.description: Finding relevant information, precedents, and expertise across existing internal systems (DMS, knowledge bases) is challenging. This results in inefficient research, potential for inconsistent advice, and an inability to fully capitalize on the organization's collective knowledge.

step1_initial_points.title: Strict Security & Data Sovereignty Mandates
step1_initial_points.description: Operating as a government legal provider imposes stringent security and data handling requirements. Any new AI solution must meet IRAP PROTECTED certification and ensure all sensitive government data is stored and processed exclusively within Australia.

step1_initial_points.title: Need for Future-Proof, Advanced Automation
step1_initial_points.description: AGS is looking beyond simple generative AI. They have a strategic need for 'agentic AI' capable of autonomous decision-making and multi-step task execution, indicating that current tools are insufficient for their long-term goal of transformative workflow automation.

step1_initial_points.title: Critical Need for System Integration
step1_initial_points.description: New AI tools must supplement, not replace, core systems like iManage Cloud, Elite 3E, and Microsoft Office. The challenge is ensuring seamless integration to avoid creating data silos, disjointed user experiences, and friction that would hinder user adoption.

step1_initial_points.title: Lack of Trust in 'Black Box' AI Outputs
step1_initial_points.description: For AI outputs to be defensible in a legal context, they must be transparent and explainable. Lawyers are professionally accountable for their work, creating a critical need to understand and verify the AI's reasoning, rather than relying on an untraceable 'black box'.

step1_initial_points.title: Generic AI Lacks Australian Legal Context
step1_initial_points.description: Standard large language models are not trained on the specific nuances of Australian law. AGS requires a solution specifically designed for Australian legal practices to ensure the accuracy and relevance of outputs related to local legislation, case law, and terminology.

step1_initial_points.title: Ensuring Performance & Scalability for Large Firm
step1_initial_points.description: The solution must perform reliably for up to 1,000 concurrent users across a national organization. Any performance issues or downtime would cause a significant, firm-wide productivity bottleneck, making scalability and high availability essential.

step1_initial_points.title: High Risk in Manual Compliance Checking
step1_initial_points.description: Manually validating that legal documents comply with numerous legislative instruments and government policies is a slow and error-prone task. This creates a significant compliance burden and exposes both AGS and its government clients to unnecessary risk.

step2_filtered_points.title: Strict Security & Data Sovereignty Mandates
step2_filtered_points.description: Operating as a government legal provider imposes stringent security and data handling requirements. Any new AI solution must meet IRAP PROTECTED certification and ensure all sensitive government data is stored and processed exclusively within Australia.

step2_filtered_points.title: Lack of Trust in 'Black Box' AI Outputs
step2_filtered_points.description: For AI outputs to be defensible in a legal context, they must be transparent and explainable. Lawyers are professionally accountable for their work, creating a critical need to understand and verify the AI's reasoning, rather than relying on an untraceable 'black box'.

step2_filtered_points.title: Generic AI Lacks Australian Legal Context
step2_filtered_points.description: Standard large language models are not trained on the specific nuances of Australian law. AGS requires a solution specifically designed for Australian legal practices to ensure the accuracy and relevance of outputs related to local legislation, case law, and terminology.

step2_filtered_points.title: Inefficient Manual Legal Workflows
step2_filtered_points.description: Lawyers spend significant time on low-value, repetitive tasks like summarizing lengthy documents, creating case chronologies, and drafting initial communications. This reduces efficiency, slows service delivery, and diverts focus from high-value strategic legal analysis.

step2_filtered_points.title: Need for Future-Proof, Advanced Automation
step2_filtered_points.description: AGS is looking beyond simple generative AI. They have a strategic need for 'agentic AI' capable of autonomous decision-making and multi-step task execution, indicating that current tools are insufficient for their long-term goal of transformative workflow automation.

step2_filtered_points.title: Difficulty Leveraging Internal Knowledge
step2_filtered_points.description: Finding relevant information, precedents, and expertise across existing internal systems (DMS, knowledge bases) is challenging. This results in inefficient research, potential for inconsistent advice, and an inability to fully capitalize on the organization's collective knowledge.

step2_filtered_points.title: Critical Need for System Integration
step2_filtered_points.description: New AI tools must supplement, not replace, core systems like iManage Cloud, Elite 3E, and Microsoft Office. The challenge is ensuring seamless integration to avoid creating data silos, disjointed user experiences, and friction that would hinder user adoption.

step2_filtered_points.title: High Risk in Manual Compliance Checking
step2_filtered_points.description: Manually validating that legal documents comply with numerous legislative instruments and government policies is a slow and error-prone task. This creates a significant compliance burden and exposes both AGS and its government clients to unnecessary risk.

step3_refined_points.title: Lack of a Trusted & Specialized Legal AI Platform
step3_refined_points.description: Generic AI fails on three critical fronts: it lacks the required IRAP PROTECTED security and Australian data sovereignty; its 'black box' nature is indefensible in legal contexts; and it isn't trained on the nuances of Australian law, creating unacceptable risk and irrelevance.

step3_refined_points.title: Inefficient Workflows Require Advanced Automation
step3_refined_points.description: Lawyers are burdened by manual, low-value tasks like document summarization and high-risk compliance checking. The strategic goal is not just simple generation, but transformative, agentic AI that can autonomously execute multi-step legal workflows and enable high-value strategic work.

step3_refined_points.title: Siloed Internal Knowledge & Poor System Integration
step3_refined_points.description: Critical internal knowledge, including precedents and expertise, is locked within siloed systems like iManage. A new AI solution must deeply integrate with these core platforms to unlock this value, prevent workflow friction, drive user adoption, and ensure consistent legal advice.

merge_decisions.kept: Lack of a Trusted & Specialized Legal AI Platform
